test_metadata.test_title: Public Administration and Governance - Practice MCQ Test
test_metadata.subject: Ethics, Integrity and Aptitude
test_metadata.sub_topic: Governance, Public Service Values, Administrative Ethics
test_metadata.description: UPSC-style MCQs on public administration, governance, ethical and citizen-centric administration, accountability and service delivery.

questions.question_text: In the context of public administration, 'governance' is best understood as:

options.option_text: The act of ruling by force
The processes and institutions through which decisions are made and authority is exercised in managing a country’s affairs
Only the activities of the legislature
Only the enforcement of criminal law

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a key feature of 'good governance'?

options.option_text: Transparency
Accountability
Arbitrariness in decision-making
Participation of stakeholders

questions.question_text: Which of the following principles of public administration focuses on simplifying processes and reducing unnecessary complexities for citizens?

options.option_text: Centralisation
Procedural rigidity
Citizen-centric service delivery and simplification
Secrecy in administration

questions.question_text: Public administration in a democratic polity is expected to be primarily oriented towards:

options.option_text: Serving political party interests only
Serving public interest and upholding constitutional values
Maximising profits like private firms
Favouring particular groups close to power

questions.question_text: The term 'New Public Management' (NPM) is generally associated with which of the following ideas?

options.option_text: Viewing citizens solely as subjects
Greater emphasis on efficiency, performance measurement and managerial techniques borrowed from private sector
Exclusive focus on hierarchy and rigid rules
Complete absence of accountability

questions.question_text: In the context of governance, 'accountability' means that public officials:

options.option_text: Are answerable for their actions and decisions to appropriate authorities or the public
Have absolute discretion without any scrutiny
Need not record reasons for their decisions
Are responsible only to their immediate family members

questions.question_text: Which one of the following mechanisms promotes 'horizontal accountability' in governance?

options.option_text: Elections of representatives by citizens
Judicial review of executive decisions by courts
Citizen participation in gram sabhas
Media debates on policy issues

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key objective of 'e-governance' initiatives in India?

options.option_text: Increasing physical paperwork
Using information and communication technologies to improve service delivery, transparency and efficiency
Centralising all decisions in a single office
Reducing citizen access to information

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is NOT a typical benefit of e-governance from an ethical governance perspective?

options.option_text: Reduction in discretionary power of lower-level officials
Improved transparency in processes
Facilitation of time-bound delivery of services
Complete elimination of the need for ethical values in officials

questions.question_text: In the context of Indian administration, 'citizen charter' is primarily aimed at:

options.option_text: Outlining citizens’ duties towards the state
Informing citizens about available services, standards, timelines and grievance redress mechanisms
Enumerating only financial rights of citizens
Providing a list of punishments for citizens

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a limitation often observed in the implementation of citizen charters in India?

options.option_text: Excessive legal enforceability of charters
Lack of awareness among citizens and weak grievance redressal mechanisms
Too much citizen participation in drafting charters
Over-simplification of procedures in all departments

questions.question_text: Public service values in administration generally include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.option_text: Integrity
Objectivity
Commitment to public interest
Blind loyalty to private corporate interests

questions.question_text: Which of the following best explains the concept of 'rule of law' in democratic governance?

options.option_text: All officials are above the law
Government and citizens are equally subject to publicly known and fairly applied laws
Law applies only to citizens, not to officials
Law is enforced only at the discretion of political leaders

questions.question_text: Which of the following is MOST closely related to 'responsive administration'?

options.option_text: Ignoring citizen complaints
Acting promptly and sensitively to citizens’ needs and feedback
Following rules mechanically without considering citizen needs
Delaying decisions to avoid responsibility

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a major advantage of decentralisation in public administration from a governance perspective?

options.option_text: Decision-making closer to people, allowing better understanding of local needs
Complete elimination of citizen participation
Concentration of power at the central level
Increased secrecy in decisions

questions.question_text: In Indian context, which of the following institutions primarily embodies local self-governance in rural areas?

options.option_text: Municipal corporations
Panchayati Raj Institutions
High Courts
Public Sector Undertakings

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key ethical challenge in public administration when there is excessive political interference in routine administrative matters?

options.option_text: Greater impartiality
Enhanced professionalism
Erosion of neutrality and merit-based decision-making
Strengthening of independent judgments

questions.question_text: Which of the following concepts emphasises partnership between government, private sector and civil society in governance?

options.option_text: Command-and-control governance
Network governance and collaborative governance
Autocratic decision-making
Exclusive state monopoly over all decisions

questions.question_text: From an ethical standpoint, 'bureaucratic red-tapism' is problematic because it often results in:

options.option_text: Efficient and speedy delivery
Unnecessary delays, harassment and denial of timely services to citizens
Greater citizen empowerment
Enhanced transparency

questions.question_text: Which of the following tools directly empowers citizens to demand accountability in service delivery at the local level through social audits and public hearings?

options.option_text: Closed-door meetings of officials
Right to Information and social audit mechanisms
Internal office circulars
Secret oral instructions

questions.question_text: In public administration, 'delegation of authority' should be accompanied by which essential ethical component to prevent misuse?

options.option_text: Unrestricted discretion without any reporting
Corresponding responsibility and accountability for decisions
Total absence of monitoring
Freedom to ignore rules completely

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is an example of 'procedural justice' in public administration?

options.option_text: Ensuring that only final outcomes are fair, procedures can be arbitrary
Providing fair, consistent and transparent processes for all applicants
Treating different groups by varying secret rules
Allowing decisions without any recording of reasons

questions.question_text: Ethical public administration requires that discretion given to officials should be exercised primarily on the basis of:

options.option_text: Personal relationships and biases
Rule of law, public interest and relevant facts
Private gain
Secret informal instructions alone

questions.question_text: In a democratic system, which of the following institutions plays a central role in enforcing executive accountability to the people?

options.option_text: Legislature through debates, questions and committees
Private companies
Foreign governments
Non-registered informal groups only

questions.question_text: From the perspective of ethics in public administration, 'transparency' primarily means that:

options.option_text: All information is kept secret from citizens
Relevant information, rules and reasons for decisions are accessible and understandable to those affected
Only internal memos are shared among officials
Citizens are not entitled to know procedures

questions.question_text: Which of the following best explains 'participatory governance'?

options.option_text: Decision-making only by top bureaucrats
Active involvement of citizens and stakeholder groups in decision-making and policy implementation
Complete outsourcing of governance to private firms
Total negation of citizen feedback mechanisms

questions.question_text: Service delivery in public administration is considered ethical when it is based on which of the following principles?

options.option_text: Arbitrary denial to some sections
Equality, fairness, non-discrimination and timeliness
Favouring only influential citizens
Providing services only against informal payments

questions.question_text: Which of the following features distinguishes 'public servants' from employees of private companies in terms of ethical obligations?

options.option_text: Obligation to maximise shareholder profits
Primary responsibility to uphold public interest and constitutional values
No obligation to follow law
Freedom to keep decisions secret from all oversight bodies

questions.question_text: Which of the following situations BEST indicates 'regulatory capture' in governance?

options.option_text: Regulator strictly enforcing laws on all firms
Regulatory agency acting in the interest of the industry it regulates instead of public interest
Regulator consulting stakeholders transparently
Regulator disclosing decisions publicly

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a direct manifestation of 'clientelism' in public administration?

options.option_text: Provision of services based on eligibility criteria
Distribution of public benefits based on political loyalty rather than merit or need
Use of objective selection criteria
Adherence to legal entitlements for all

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major ethical risk associated with excessive outsourcing of public services to private entities?

options.option_text: Improved flexibility and innovation
Potential dilution of public accountability and public service values
Higher citizen participation
Greater transparency in all cases

questions.question_text: The idea of 'minimum government, maximum governance' implies, from an ethical governance perspective, that the state should:

options.option_text: Withdraw from all responsibilities
Focus on core functions, reduce red tape and enable efficient, citizen-friendly service delivery
Control all aspects of citizens’ personal lives
Increase number of rules without simplifying processes

questions.question_text: From an ethical standpoint, performance appraisal systems in public administration should primarily aim to:

options.option_text: Promote favouritism
Recognise merit, encourage ethical performance and identify training needs objectively
Reward only outputs, ignoring integrity
Discourage initiative by penalising risk-takers indiscriminately

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an important ethical consideration in the use of data and technology in governance?

options.option_text: Ignoring citizens’ privacy and consent
Ensuring data protection, privacy and non-discriminatory use of algorithms
Using data for surveillance of political opponents only
Keeping all algorithms secret from any scrutiny

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is a key indicator of 'ethical climate' in an organisation?

options.option_text: Prevalence of fear and secrecy
Employees feel safe to raise ethical concerns and wrongdoing is not tolerated
Frequent reward for results achieved by any means
Absence of any discussion on ethics

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'grievance redress mechanism' in public administration?

options.option_text: Internal transfers based on favouritism
Lokpal, Lokayuktas, departmental grievance cells and online complaint portals
Secret informal arrangements
Private arbitration for all public complaints

questions.question_text: Ethical leadership in governance primarily requires that leaders should:

options.option_text: Set personal examples of integrity and fairness, and encourage ethical behaviour in others
Focus only on short-term popularity
Avoid taking any difficult decisions
Encourage blind obedience among subordinates

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate benchmark for ethical evaluation of public policies in a constitutional democracy?

options.option_text: Personal preferences of administrators
Alignment with constitutional values, human rights and public interest
Short-term political gains alone
Benefits to a small elite group

questions.question_text: Which of the following illustrates the ethical principle of 'subsidiarity' in governance?

options.option_text: Always centralising powers at the national level
Ensuring that decisions are taken at the lowest competent level close to the people
Delegating all decisions to international agencies
Allowing no role for local bodies in governance

questions.question_text: From an ethical governance perspective, public consultation before major policy changes helps in:

options.option_text: Reducing legitimacy of policies
Enhancing legitimacy, trust and inclusiveness in decision-making
Ensuring secrecy of government decisions
Excluding marginalised groups from discussion

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST represents a conflict between 'efficiency' and 'equity' in public administration?

options.option_text: Choosing only fastest processes even if they systematically exclude weaker sections
Providing additional support to marginalised groups for fair access
Reducing corruption
Improving the quality of data systems

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'ethical neutrality' being misused in public administration?

options.option_text: An officer applying law fairly to all
An officer silently implementing orders that violate fundamental rights without raising concern
An officer recusing from a case due to conflict of interest
An officer recording dissenting note through proper channels

questions.question_text: From an ethical standpoint, 'street-level bureaucrats' (like frontline officials) are important because they:

options.option_text: Have no discretion and only process files
Directly interact with citizens and effectively shape how policies are experienced on the ground
Work only with computers and not with people
Decide only internal office rules

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements is MOST crucial to ensure that grievance redress mechanisms are actually effective from a citizen’s perspective?

options.option_text: Complex and lengthy procedures
Time-bound resolution, accessibility and feedback to complainants
Lack of monitoring of resolved cases
Non-availability of appeal mechanisms

questions.question_text: Which one of the following illustrates an ethical use of discretion by a public servant?

options.option_text: Relaxing rules arbitrarily for friends
Interpreting rules in a humane manner to provide urgent help within legal limits
Ignoring rules completely in all cases
Using discretion to delay services as a means of harassment

questions.question_text: Which of the following represents an ethical approach to managing performance targets in public programmes?

options.option_text: Manipulating data to show targets achieved
Setting realistic targets, monitoring honestly and learning from shortfalls
Setting impossible targets to impress superiors
Ignoring any evaluation

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements of organisational design is MOST likely to reduce unethical behaviour in public agencies?

options.option_text: Ambiguous responsibilities and overlapping roles
Clear roles, checks and balances, and separation of powers
Concentration of all power in one individual
Lack of documentation requirements

questions.question_text: From an ethical governance perspective, which of the following is MOST appropriate when an officer faces conflicting instructions from political and administrative superiors?

options.option_text: Follow any instruction that brings personal benefit
Prioritise instructions that are legal, in public interest and consistent with rules; record written directions for contentious orders
Always follow oral political instructions
Ignore legal provisions to maintain relationships

questions.question_text: Which one of the following BEST explains the importance of 'ethical training' for civil servants?

options.option_text: To ensure they memorise all rules without understanding values
To build moral awareness, reasoning skills and commitment to public service values
To teach techniques of avoiding accountability
To train them only in technical procedures

questions.question_text: Ethical public administration ultimately aims to achieve which of the following broad outcomes in a democratic society?

options.option_text: Concentration of benefits among a small elite
Trustworthy, fair and effective governance that upholds rights and promotes common good
Complete withdrawal of state from welfare activities
Maximum secrecy and minimum citizen participation
